body: @jwang98052 is this ready to be merged? I've updated IMRUCloseTaskTest in this PR to handle the failed Evaluator scenario, that is why it is passing.
This will conflict with #1042. I'll perform the merge when one of them gets merged into master. Thanks!
LGTM.
LGTM will merge
@afchung I see you modified TaskCloseTest, but didn't find the change for IMRUCloseTaskTest. Did I miss it?

We can add new packages not to the project itself but to the solution directly, Solution -> Manage NuGet packages for solution. This will remove the need for manual move.

I've updated PR. Alternative option is to keep per-project `package.config`s but keep them empty - but that makes it tempting to add packages for individual projects again.

@jwang98052 it seems like I didn't need to change it since the Tasks always complete. My understanding taking a glance as the code is that what the test does is it just runs broadcast and reduce without injecting any failure and hence there is no need for us to close the Tasks. Given that TestBroadcastAndReduce always runs until the Driver is completed, we always wait for all Tasks to finish.
We should probably change that test to include deterministic, injected failures.
@markusweimer Do you suggest to handle refactoring in this PR or track it with a new JIRA issue?

@afchung The test send close event to every task. First task should close with CompletedTask, others, in most cases will stuck in data reading and eventually exception will be throw. With old behavior, it should end up to FailedTask. With new behavior, it will end up to FailedEvaluator, Now they all end up to CompletedTask, that is why I don't understand. Looks like they are all completed before receiving close event.

I have changed it with REEF-1466, the behavior will be deterministic.
Should we merge REEF-1466 first then? What do you suggest? I'm not familiar with the test so I will not be modifying it.

Theoretically, we should merge REEF-1469 first, I will then need to update REEF-1466 to resolve the conflict. Then REEF-1447. But if you have any dependency on it, we might want to move quicker as you have limited days left and I will ensure this test work eventually.

I have a few more tests that depend on classes in this PR (see #1057). Alternatively we can try to merge #1057 first. Either way I would like to get `WaitingTask` and `EventHandle` into the main codebase first.
I will look #1057 as early as I can. Would it conflict with this one #1042?
I will have a look.

Instead of increasing the retry count, I'm wondering if it might make more sense to switch to exponential backoff.
@afchung  LGTM
@jwang98052 @markusweimer I've resolved the conflict and rebased. Thanks!

@afchung I am not sure of that...In many cases in Group communication retries are needed not because currently there is some transient fault and hence exponential strategy makes sure that we do not check too soon in future if fault happens now, but because evaluator might be busy setting itself up with data loading (common scenario), before actually calling the group communication operators where registration happens. Since master typically does not have data, it enters registration earlier and hence times out if its children are loading a large amount of data. Same thing can happen if cluster is busy and there is some latency in getting all the evaluators, although in this case exponential back off makes more sense :)
I will test and merge.

When adding a NuGet at project level, it will automatically add the dll references in the project. We don't want to add the references to all the projects in the solution. We don't want to only add NuGet in the sln package file and manually add those references to a particular project either, right?
@tcNickolas Looks great. One question though: why did you leave the deprecated code in `CommunicationGroupDriverImpl` untouched? It was originally on the JIRA description, right?

Because for it deprecated constructor is used in code, and switch from explicit constructor call to injection is not quite trivial because two constructors have different sets of parameters. I've filed REEF-1488 for it so that it is not forgotten.
Oh, didn't notice 1488. If so, this is safe to be merged. I'll merge this.
Hi @markusweimer and @jieunparklee, I've just merged and tested everything on my PC - there are no conflicts, and the build is fine. Do you want me to push the new master to the main repo?
@motus +1 from me

I allocated today to try the refactor, the idea is to make 
EvaluatorManager: IObserver<IDriverStarted>, IObserver<IAllocatedEvaluator>, IObserver<IFailedEvaluator>
ActiveContextManager : IDisposable, IObservable<IEnumerable<IActiveContext>>, IObserver<IActiveContext>, IObserver<IFailedContext>
TaskManager : IObserver<ICompletedTask>, IObserver<IFailedTask>, IObserver<IRunningTask>, IObserver<IEnumerable<IActiveContext>>

That basically means, copy paste all the handlers in IMRUDriver to those three managers. IMRUDriver is almost gone, however, the same code goes to those managers. There is nothing reduced. 

And it introduced a lot of complexity. 
1. All the managers need to know each other. e.g. in FailedEvaluator, it needs to inform Context manger to remove failed Context in the failed evaluator and Task Manager to record failed task. In Task Manager, it needs to ask Evaluator manager if EvaluatorId in IActiveContext is a master Evaluator. 
2. Since those are handlers, they must be injectable. That's fine. The result is most of the parameters in IMRUDriver constructor are copied to all the three managers. make every constructor complex. 
3. As some of the code needs to use <TMapInput, TMapOutput, TResult, TPartitionType>, it ends up each manager has to be generic with those Ts. Make the code looks complex.
4. The code IsRecoverable() and RecoveryAction() etc need to access all the three managers. So it may end up a FaultManager. As the three managers need to reference this class as well. I tried future injection, it doesn't work out. 
I am half way of the refactoring, so far I don't see the code is significantly simplified but more complex. 
Given the time constrains, I would suggest to complete the review of the current version. Make the logic work first. If we still like to refactor it, we can leave it as a separate Jira as it would be purely refactor.
@motus Yes please. Thank you

@jwang98052  done with another pass....I am finding the CloseEvent test a bit hard to understand....it would be good to document what to expect form it - how many failed tasks, failed evaluator (if any) etc.
My understanding is that we should not get any failed evaluators since tasks are all signaled by driver and hence should either close properly or give IFailedTask messages?

I'll merge this with two changes: fix typo `ContextId1 -> ContextId0` and replace `ContextStartExceptionTask` in `ContextStartExceptionTest` with `NullTask` (which I guess was the intention of introducing it as a separate class).
